ResponsesInList.Title: Mobile app (Android) Audio upload: File format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Folks, (I haven't been able to find a topic about this here, or on the wider web, so here goes...) In the current Mobile app (4.1.1), under Android, the audio upload is being saved in WHICH file format? (I thought it might be WAV or OGG.) Does anyone know?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mobile app (Android) Audio upload: File format?
ResponsesInList.Text: We recently changed this in the app, so if you're using the built-in audio recorder it should be creating the files in `mp3` . You can read up on the details here: MOBILE-2314 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mobile app (Android) Audio upload: File format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Noel (and everyone), Maybe you all already knew this, but the mimetype of the MPEG file that the Android mobile app creates is "audio/mpeg". (We use a Moodle plugin called "Antivirus Mime Blocker" to restrict the upload of many file types (like WAV audio and MP4 video), and we'd allowed "audio/m4a" and audio/mp3", but not audio/mpeg".)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mobile app (Android) Audio upload: File format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey, thanks for letting us know. Just to be sure, I double-checked this list of common mime types and mp3 files are listed as `audio/mpeg` so it seems like what the app is doing is correct.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Having trouble during installation of latest moodle mobile code (4.1.1)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, we currently use Node v14.15.0 (it's in .nvmrc) and npm 6 (which is the version that comes with Node 14, in my local environment it's v6.14.17). Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Having trouble during installation of latest moodle mobile code (4.1.1)
ResponsesInList.Text: How do you manage to build with ionic since there is deprecation message about node 14 now, and it automatically fails.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Having trouble during installation of latest moodle mobile code (4.1.1)
ResponsesInList.Text: You're probably getting this message because you're using the latest version of Ionic, but we're still using an old version (Ionic 5). To make sure that the build commands are using the proper ionic version, you should run them from the scripts. So for example, doing `npm run build` instead of `ionic build` . If you still want to run some command that isn't defined in the scripts, you should be able to run it using the proper ionic-cli version doing `npx ionic ...` . More info here: Setting up your development environment for the Moodle App

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Mobile Gamification Application Supoort
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If you want your custom plugins to work in the mobile app you will have to package them as remote add-ons ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Moodle_Mobile_Remote_addons ) Basically, the overall idea is that you create a Moodle plugin that includes a Moodle Mobile add-on, the app will download and lazy load your Mobile add-on Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Local dev server & trusted SSL Certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nicolas, the trusted SSL Certificate is an Android/iOS limitation, we can't change that. You can just use the browser for the early stages of development and then test the development in your production server. See: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Moodle_Mobile_development_using_Chrome_or_Chromium Or, you can hack your internal server config.php so it also works  via http (changing the wwwroot dinamically) Regards, Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom moodle mobile app
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Unfortunately our core team do not have the resources here to help people use the open source code version (this include maintain all the development documentation update). We provide a service where we can customise the app for anyone who needs it including the Push notifications (Airnotifier) service management. This service helps fund the improvement of the app in general: https://moodle.com/mobileapp/ In any case, there are several developers in this forum that created custom version of the app, you could always request help from the community.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom moodle mobile app
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Juan, for your reply. I totally understand that maintaining documents is a time-consuming task and needs a lot of efforts and time that is preferred to be spent on the actual development. I have a little concern and really appreciate if you or anyone from the core team can elaborate a bit more. The Custom Mobile app creation service that Moodle HQ offers is surely a valuable service but is it going to threaten the availability of the Moodle App source code to the public in any way in future? You are right about the existence of developers with significant achievements with Moodle Mobile App. However, there are many other developers on the other hand, that need a little help to start so that they can contribute to the development of the app and maybe in near future you would have enough contributions from the wider community to give you enough time to take care of maintaining docs. I believe this is happening for the Moodle code itself and there are many non-HQ contributors that raise bugs, provide patches to fix bugs, propose new features and sometimes provide patches to implement their proposal. I don't see this happening for the mobile app though. Obviously, I don't have enough information about what's going on as you have and I might be 100 percent wrong. But I think that Moodle is depriving itself of potential contributions by not maintaining the development documents. It is worth to consider that many people that are involved in Moodle development in any way do not have Cordova development background. Many of them are experienced PHP developers, but they need some help to start riding a new horse.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom moodle mobile app
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, we'll be maintaining the developer docs and the upgrade.txt file in the mobile app source code with changes that may affect developers. But, honestly, we have limited resources so we can't support or provide any additional documentation for people creating custom apps. Regarding contributions, we haven't received much, but we've received more than expected . Developing for the mobile app usually requires a good understanding of Moodle and a good knowledge of the technologies used in the mobile app, and that's not easy. In brief: the Mobile app documentation (both users and developers) will be keep updated but not tutorials or specific documentation for creating custom apps.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to remove "Site Home" tab in Moodle Mobile app through CoreMainMenuHomeDelegate?
ResponsesInList.Text:
In Moodle Academy course in creating Make your plugin mobile app compatible Greetings tab is added to the mobile app using CoreMainMenuHomeDelegate . Is there a way to use CoreMainMenuHomeDelegate to remove Site-Home
tab? How can I remove the Site-Home tab from the Moodle Mobile App? Please help. I have read Moodle docs but I am unable to find a way to use this delegate to remove tabs from mobile app. Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to remove "Site Home" tab in Moodle Mobile app through CoreMainMenuHomeDelegate?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, in a browser, login as admin and go to "Site administration > Mobile app > Mobile features". Inside "Disabled features", select the option "Site home" (it's inside "Main menu") and save changes. After you restart the app you should no longer see the Site home tab. Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to remove "Site Home" tab in Moodle Mobile app through CoreMainMenuHomeDelegate?
ResponsesInList.Text: That worked, Thanks a lot!

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Mobile App for Moodle Release 2.5.4 (Build: 20140113)
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi there, We currently have Moodle Release 2.5.4 in which we are aiming to integrate the Moodle Mobile App. We have the mobile app downloaded onto a IOS device however when logging in, the message below appears: Access Control Exception. We have worked our way through the following suggestions: What is the 'Access control exception' error It means that one of this admin setting has failed: authorised user: ip restriction fails to authenticate the user
(Administration > Plugins > Web services > Manage services >
Authorized users > click on user full name) authorised user: valid date is expired (Administration > Plugins
> Web services > Manage services > Authorized users > click
on user full name) admin created the token: ip restriction fails to authenticate the
user (Administration > Plugins > Web services > Manage tokens
> check the status) admin created the token: valid date is expired (Administration >
Plugins > Web services > Manage tokens > check the status) the user is not listed in the authorized list (Administration >
Plugins > Web services > Manage services > Authorized users) the user hasn't the required capability (Administration > Plugins > Web services > Manage services > Edit service) site in maintenance mode user is suspended user is not confirmed user is deleted the user authentication is set to nologin (edit the user profile) password expired (most likely happens with external authentication like LDAP ) web service disabled (Administration > Advanced features) user doesn't have the capability to use the used web service
protocol (user should have the capability
'webservice/use:xmlrpc'/'webservice/use:rest'/..., on SYSTEM context ). the user token doesn't exist the web service function is not included in the service Since Moodle 2.2, if the administrator turns Moodle debug mode >= NORMAL, then an explicit error message will be returned. Can anyone guide?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Mobile App for Moodle Release 2.5.4 (Build: 20140113)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, the Moodle app only supports Moodle 3.1 or higher. That isn't related to the 'Access control exception' error you're facing, that's a different issue, but you won't be able to access that site using the app even if you fix the error. We used to support sites from Moodle 2.4, but we increased it to 3.1 a couple of years ago because it was a pain for us to maintain those old versions. Cheers,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS for Mobile App
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nitesh, you have posted your CSS in the correct place. Some themes have a box within that theme's settings where you can add CSS - but I personally use the Additional HTML option in the main, as it saves me having to move the CSS when changing themes. In terms of updating the mobile app, this is much trickier - I have created a blog post on this https://davefoord.wordpress.com/2023/05/31/moodle-tricks-of-the-trade-adding-your-own-css-to-the-moodle-mobile-app/ But - this only works if you have a premium account , if you don't then you cannot change the CSS at all within the mobile app. And finally - I know it isn't the purpose of your question, but I would get someone to check the CSS you are adding: From an accessibility perspective - fully justifying text is not a good idea, and where you have set a specific size for the fonts, this would be better using relative sizes e.g. rem rather than px

ResponsesInList.Title: Mobile app usage
ResponsesInList.Text:
I am creating some SQL queries to find out about Moodle mobile app usage. There is a table called user_devices that records information from the app and includes a lastmodified column. It looks like the mobile token will by default expire every 12 weeks. So a query on records that have been updated in the last year will typically indicate that a user has used the app at least once in that period. Combining that with lastlogin data from the user table should give a finer grain of information.

I am currently working with this query to count the numbers of “logins” using the mobile app over the last 12 months (or settable period of time), using report_customsql

SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT ud.userid) AS users_who_have_logged_in
FROM {user_devices} ud
JOIN {user} u ON u.id = ud.userid
WHERE u.lastlogin >= :since_lastlogin_date
AND ud.timemodified >= :since_timemodified_date

All feedback is greatly appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Mobile app usage
ResponsesInList.Text:
To make that query a little easier to read ... 
```text
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT ud.userid) AS users_who_have_logged_in
FROM {user_devices} ud
JOIN {user} u ON u.id = ud.userid
WHERE u.lastlogin >= :since_lastlogin_date
AND ud.timemodified >= :since_timemodified_date
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Mobile app usage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marcus, the query seems to be correct, but I'd personally validate that it works as expected, just testing with a user accessing exclusively via the mobile app to the site, another user using both, and testing that the query returns the expected situations for all the possible use cases Regards, Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: Web service function called	The web service function 'core_message_get_messages' has been called.
ResponsesInList.Text: Please Help A teacher sent a message to a user. The logs shows that the student viewed the message and later logged out at 13:35 . At 13:47 until 23: 52 the logs indicate a systems event for this user: "Web service function called. The web service function 'core_message_get_messages' has been called." That is Sixteen thousand (16000) of these webservice function calls in a 10 hour period. How can i stop this. We are running moodle 3.1.18 on an ubuntu server .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Web service function called	The web service function 'core_message_get_messages' has been called.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, are those 16000 events for the same user? The app can call this WS quite a lot if the user has the discussion open in the app because we try to fetch the messages every 10 seconds, but 16000 in 10 hours sounds too much (it's more than 25 calls per minute!). In Moodle 3.6 the messaging system was improved and the amount of WS calls needed when viewing a discussion was reduced, maybe that can help you reduce the number of WS calls. You can disable the messaging in the app using the Moodle mobile additional features plugin . Install the plugin, go to "Site administration > Plugins > Local plugins > Moodle Mobile additional features > Disabled features" and select these options: Main menu: Messages User: Send message Please notice that users won't be able to view or send messages in the app after changing this, they'll have to do it in browser. Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Statistics of user devices
ResponsesInList.Text: It would be great to have stats on: The specifics of the device(s) a user has logged onto the Moodle site with and how many are currently active (logged in and having a connection at least once in 30 days) A boolean profile field that is called "Mobile user". 'Yes' when a user has registered (logged in with) at least one device and has made a connection using the app the last 30 days. It is 'No' when the user has not registered a device or after 30 days of no connection. The specifics would mean: -The OS (Android/iOS, version numbers) -The resolution of the user -What version of the Moodle app they have installed This will clear the way for some great new functionality. Administrators can identify what devices their users are on (and identify possible OS/device specific issues). Also, with the "Mobile User" field, plugins can start sending automated messages to users that will be pushed to their devices. When they are not a "Mobiile User", an email can be sent to those users as fallback option. I'm interested to hear your thoughts! Would you want this info as well? Do you have additional wishes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Statistics of user devices
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle already has a table.   Try this query: select concat('',userid,''), concat('',model,''), platform,version from `mdl_user_devices; and output to an html page - named however - to your moodlecode/local/ directory to view via web. 'spirit of sharing', Ken

ResponsesInList.Title: Why aren't all the webservices supported in MM?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, In the list of webservice APIs functions provided, the "services" column has no description as what exactly it is whether it means mobile app support or anything else. Considering it is mobile support then a lot of these webservices aren't supported by mobile app. Is it because some of these webservices are simply not useful in a mobile scenario therefore not implemented or is there a design or implementation issue regarding availability for mobile. Or maybe just they had low priority and there was not enough dev time for them? What I'm trying to understand here is that if anyone wanted to use any of these (supposedly?) unsupported webservices for mobile app would there be a way to make such webservice available to app? How would a webservice be suitable to be used in a mobile app or not?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why aren't all the webservices supported in MM?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Farzin, we only include the WebServices that we need in the Mobile app. This is because some WebServices don't make sense for the Mobile app, and for security reasons (the less available WebServices, the less actions an attacker can do if he gets your token). If you want to add more WebServices to the MM service, you can do it in your site by adding this in the WebService: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/mod/lesson/db/services.php#L45 Also, if you have a plugin that includes new WebServices they can be added to the MM service too. Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Problem with Android app v1.15 on tablets
ResponsesInList.Text: We are having a problem with the Android app user interface on our tablet devices. We are running Moodle 2.7.3+ (Build: 20141211) and v1.15 of the Android app. The app works very well on our phones but on our tablets we cannot navigate past the selection of a course. When the app is started on a tablet and a user logs in, you are presented with the welcome screen and the main menu. Selecting items on the main menu seems to work fine. If you select My Courses the drop down menu of available courses expands. Selecting a course causes the drop down menu of "Contents, Participants, Grades" to appear. Clicking on Contents refreshes the display and presents two columns. The left column is a menu of the course sections and the right column shows the contents of the General section. At this point the options in the left menu (which should allow selection of different course sections) becomes unresponsive. In addition you cannot select any of the resources displayed in the right pane. Long-pressing any of the Section items in the left pane does highlight the item (indicating that the press is being registered) but nothing happens. The same for the resources in the right pane. Selecting the "info" icon or download icon (where they are available) does register correctly. We have tried this on several tablets and all behave similarly. I fully expected to see someone else reporting the problem here or in the bug tracker. Any assistance would be appreciated. We are looking forward to v2 of the app.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Iphone not registering
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, please note that local_mobile does not handle the device registration, this is done by the message_airnotifier plugin that has been in core since 2.7 If your devices are being registered in external_devices but not in the airnotifier table this is because Airnotifier is not being capable of validating the device. Please, send me your production key via PM so I can check if it is valid. Regards, Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: This might not be a new "issue" but why is H5P not showing content on the mobile app? allowframembedding is on Im seeing a login promt instead of the content. I have read about problems regarding this back in 2017+ but has there ben any fix for this? Or do we need to turn the function of in mobile app? Best regards Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, if you're using an iOS device, please go to the iOS Settings (not the Moodle app settings), search for "Moodle" in there and enable "Allow Cross-Website Tracking". If you're using an Android device or that isn't working, do you know if your site is using the mod_hvp plugin or it uses the h5p system integrated in Moodle core? Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Dani thank you for a fast reply. You got me there, i do have the mod_hvp installed, and Im guessing thats what we created the content with. I can see that there is a migration tool in plugin. Do I need to install anything before migration, and can i safely remove the mod_hvp afterwards? of course I backup everything, but just so I know whats awaits me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, the mod_hvp plugin should work in the app, if it asks for authentication then there are 2 possible issues AFAIK : Cookies are blocked (e.g. because of the iOS setting I mentioned in my previous post). Our auto-login feature isn't working. There are some restrictions to make it work: - The site must use https. - The user cannot be an admin. - There is a time limit for consecutive uses (by default, 6 minutes). This means that if you see a mod_hvp in the app with user A and then you see a mod_hvp in another device with the same user before 6 minutes have passed, the second one will not work as expected (you'll see the login page). We don't maintain the mod_hvp plugin, but a lot of sites are you using so I think it should work as expected in the app. IMO you should be able to make it work without migrating to the core h5p. Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Ang: Re: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you so much. We will wait a little before migrating then. I got it working using a demo student user, i think it might be the admin user the made it fail. Have a nice weekend, and once again thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Dani, I'm currently experiencing the same issue Michael mentioned (both on iOS and Android). The only difference is that we first create the H5P in the content bank and then embed it in a Label (Text and Media Area since Moodle 4), we do this because our client requested to see H5P activities directly inside the course page without having the user to click on each H5P activity and navigate on a separate page in order to do the exercises.. I debugged the app both on iOS and Android, both show a login form instead of the h5p content and if I debug the app in the Chrome inspection console I get two error messages: 
```text
GET
 
https://xxx.xxx/admin/tool/mobile/autologin.php?userid=
... 
404 (Not found)
```
 
```text
Blocked a frame with origin 
"xxx.xxx
"
 from accessing a cross-origin frame
```
 This is what I've checked so far : We use the core h5p plugin (not the mod_hvp) On our site everything is set as explained in the documentation ( allow frame mbedding enabled, etc.) Allow Cross-Website Tracking is set on iOS CORS header set in the root .htaccess file of our site (Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*") I really don't have a clue what else could be causing this embed issue...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ivan, I just tested an H5P embedded in a label in one of our testing sites and it seems to be working fine for me (I tested Android only). Based on the console you sent, it seems your site is returning a 404 for the autologin request. Can you please verify that the URL https://xxx.xxx/admin/tool/mobile/autologin.php can be accessed in your site? Maybe your server configuration is restricting the access. Cheers, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ang: Re: H5P in Mobile APP
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dani, Thanks for getting back to me! I had a meeting with our IT department and they've found a setting in our apache2 virtual host configuration which had the X-Frame-Options set to SAMEORIGIN , after commenting it out everything seems to be working again . That setting was probably overriding our .htaccess and all the other configurations on the server... Thank you for your help! Ivan
